_link.title: I can describe power as the rate of energy transfer

toLevel2.question: What is electrical power?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Power measures how quickly energy is transferred. A higher power means more energy is converted each second.
distractors: The total amount of energy stored in a battery
The total charge in a circuit
The speed of electrons in a wire
toLevel2.correct: The rate at which electrical energy is transferred or converted

toLevel2.question: What is the SI unit of power?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The watt is the SI unit of power. One watt equals one joule of energy transferred per second (1 W = 1 J/s).

toLevel2.question: What does a power rating of 60 W on a light bulb mean?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: A 60 W rating means the bulb transforms 60 joules of electrical energy into light and heat each second it operates.
toLevel2.correct: The bulb converts 60 joules of electrical energy every second

toLevel2.question: Which formula correctly shows the relationship between power, energy, and time?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Power (P) equals energy (E) divided by time (t). This shows power is the rate of energy transfer.

toLevel2.question: If a heater transfers 1000 J of energy in 10 seconds, what is its power?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Using P = E/t = 1000 J ÷ 10 s = 100 W. The heater transfers energy at a rate of 100 watts.

toLevel2.sentence: Power is the {{blank:1}} at which energy is transferred in a circuit.

1.correctExplanation: Power describes how fast energy is converted, not the total amount. It is measured in joules per second (watts).

distractors.explanation: Power describes how fast energy is converted, not the total amount. It is measured in joules per second (watts).
Power describes how fast energy is converted, not the total amount. It is measured in joules per second (watts).
Power describes how fast energy is converted, not the total amount. It is measured in joules per second (watts).

toLevel2.sentence: One watt is equal to one {{blank:1}} of energy transferred per second.

1.correctExplanation: By definition, 1 W = 1 J/s. This connects the unit of power to the unit of energy and time.

distractors.explanation: By definition, 1 W = 1 J/s. This connects the unit of power to the unit of energy and time.
By definition, 1 W = 1 J/s. This connects the unit of power to the unit of energy and time.
By definition, 1 W = 1 J/s. This connects the unit of power to the unit of energy and time.

toLevel2.sentence: A 1000 W appliance can also be described as having a power of 1 {{blank:1}}.

1.correctExplanation: The prefix 'kilo' means 1000. So 1 kilowatt (kW) = 1000 watts. This unit is commonly used for household appliances.

distractors.explanation: The prefix 'kilo' means 1000. So 1 kilowatt (kW) = 1000 watts. This unit is commonly used for household appliances.
The prefix 'kilo' means 1000. So 1 kilowatt (kW) = 1000 watts. This unit is commonly used for household appliances.
The prefix 'kilo' means 1000. So 1 kilowatt (kW) = 1000 watts. This unit is commonly used for household appliances.

toLevel2.question: A 100 W light bulb transfers more energy per second than a 60 W light bulb.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Higher power means a faster rate of energy transfer. The 100 W bulb converts 100 J/s compared to 60 J/s for the 60 W bulb.

distractors.explanation: Higher power means a faster rate of energy transfer. The 100 W bulb converts 100 J/s compared to 60 J/s for the 60 W bulb.

toLevel2.question: Power and energy are the same thing.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Power is the rate of energy transfer (joules per second), while energy is the total amount transferred (joules). A low-power device can transfer the same total energy as a high-power one — it just takes longer.

distractors.explanation: Power is the rate of energy transfer (joules per second), while energy is the total amount transferred (joules). A low-power device can transfer the same total energy as a high-power one — it just takes longer.

toLevel3.question: A 2000 W kettle takes 3 minutes to boil water. How much energy does it use?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: E = P × t = 2000 W × 180 s = 360,000 J = 360 kJ. Remember to convert minutes to seconds.

toLevel3.question: Two heaters both deliver 5000 J of energy. Heater A does it in 10 s and Heater B in 50 s. Compare their power.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: A: P = 5000/10 = 500 W. B: P = 5000/50 = 100 W. Both transfer the same energy, but A does it faster, so it has higher power.
distractors: Both have the same power since they transfer the same energy
Heater B is more powerful because it takes longer
Power cannot be compared without knowing voltage
toLevel3.correct: Heater A has 500 W; Heater B has 100 W — A is more powerful

toLevel3.question: What is the relationship between kilowatt-hours (kWh) and joules?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: 1 kWh = 1000 W × 3600 s = 3,600,000 J. The kilowatt-hour is a unit of energy used by electricity companies for billing.
distractors: They measure different quantities and cannot be converted

toLevel3.question: An electricity bill charges 30 cents per kWh. How much does it cost to run a 2400 W heater for 5 hours?
Why is a 100 W LED bulb brighter than a 100 W incandescent bulb?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: LEDs are more efficient, converting more electrical energy to light rather than heat. A 10-15 W LED produces the same brightness as a 100 W incandescent bulb.
distractors: Both produce identical brightness at the same power
Power has no relationship to brightness
toLevel3.correct: This premise is incorrect — a 100 W LED would actually be extremely bright; LEDs achieve the same brightness as incandescent bulbs at much lower wattage

toLevel3.question: What does a power station's output of 500 MW mean?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: 500 MW = 500 × 10⁶ W = 5 × 10⁸ J/s. The power station converts 500 million joules of energy per second.
distractors: It uses 500 million watts per hour
toLevel3.correct: It transfers 500 million joules of energy every second

toLevel3.sentence: The kilowatt-hour (kWh) is a unit of {{blank:1}}, not power, used for electricity billing.

1.correctExplanation: Although it contains 'watt' (a power unit), multiplying by hours (time) gives energy: kWh = kW × h. Energy = power × time.

distractors.explanation: Although it contains 'watt' (a power unit), multiplying by hours (time) gives energy: kWh = kW × h. Energy = power × time.
Although it contains 'watt' (a power unit), multiplying by hours (time) gives energy: kWh = kW × h. Energy = power × time.
Although it contains 'watt' (a power unit), multiplying by hours (time) gives energy: kWh = kW × h. Energy = power × time.

toLevel3.sentence: To find total energy transferred, rearrange P = E/t to get E = {{blank:1}}.

1.correctExplanation: Multiplying both sides of P = E/t by t gives E = P × t. Energy equals power multiplied by time.

distractors.explanation: Multiplying both sides of P = E/t by t gives E = P × t. Energy equals power multiplied by time.
Multiplying both sides of P = E/t by t gives E = P × t. Energy equals power multiplied by time.
Multiplying both sides of P = E/t by t gives E = P × t. Energy equals power multiplied by time.

toLevel3.sentence: The prefix mega (M) means {{blank:1}}, so 1 MW = 1,000,000 W.

1.correctExplanation: Mega (M) = 10⁶ = 1,000,000. This prefix is commonly used for large power outputs like power stations.

distractors.explanation: Mega (M) = 10⁶ = 1,000,000. This prefix is commonly used for large power outputs like power stations.
Mega (M) = 10⁶ = 1,000,000. This prefix is commonly used for large power outputs like power stations.
Mega (M) = 10⁶ = 1,000,000. This prefix is commonly used for large power outputs like power stations.

toLevel3.question: A device with higher power always uses more total energy than a lower-power device.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Total energy depends on both power and time (E = Pt). A 1000 W heater running for 1 second uses less energy (1000 J) than a 100 W lamp running for 100 seconds (10,000 J).

distractors.explanation: Total energy depends on both power and time (E = Pt). A 1000 W heater running for 1 second uses less energy (1000 J) than a 100 W lamp running for 100 seconds (10,000 J).

toLevel4.question: A household uses 15 kWh of energy per day. What is the average power consumption?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Average P = E/t = 15 kWh ÷ 24 h = 0.625 kW = 625 W. This is the average rate of energy use throughout the day.

toLevel4.question: A solar panel delivers 300 W for 5 hours of sunlight per day. How many days would it take to generate 1 kWh of energy?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Daily energy = 0.3 kW × 5 h = 1.5 kWh per day. Time for 1 kWh = 1/1.5 ≈ 0.67 days. The panel produces 1 kWh in less than one day.

toLevel4.question: Compare the energy cost of running a 2 kW heater for 30 minutes versus a 500 W computer for 4 hours at the same electricity rate.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Heater: 2 kW × 0.5 h = 1 kWh. Computer: 0.5 kW × 4 h = 2 kWh. Wait — actually the computer uses 2 kWh, so it costs twice as much.
distractors: The heater costs four times more
The computer costs four times more
The heater always costs more due to higher power
toLevel4.correct: Both cost the same — each uses 1 kWh of energy

toLevel4.question: A device is rated at 240 V, 1200 W. If the voltage drops to 220 V and resistance stays constant, what happens to the power?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: For constant R, P = V²/R. Ratio: (220/240)² = 0.84. New power ≈ 0.84 × 1200 = 1008 W. Power drops with the square of voltage.
toLevel4.correct: Power decreases to about 1008 W because P ∝ V² for constant resistance

toLevel4.question: An energy-efficient appliance is rated 800 W and replaces a 1200 W model. Both run for 6 hours daily. Calculate the annual energy saving.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Daily saving = (1200 - 800) W × 6 h = 2400 Wh = 2.4 kWh/day. Annual = 2.4 × 365 = 876 kWh per year.

toLevel4.question: A phone charger is rated 5 V, 2 A. How much energy does it deliver to the phone in 2 hours of charging?
Why do electricity companies charge per kWh rather than per watt?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Customers use energy, not power. A kWh measures total energy consumed. Power (kW) tells the rate, but the bill depends on how much total energy was used.
distractors: Because watts are too small to measure
Because power and energy are the same thing
Because kilowatt-hours are easier to spell
toLevel4.correct: Because they charge for total energy consumed, not the rate of consumption

toLevel4.sentence: When voltage drops but resistance stays constant, power decreases with the {{blank:1}} of the voltage ratio.

1.correctExplanation: Since P = V²/R, power is proportional to V². If voltage halves, power reduces to one quarter of its original value.

distractors.explanation: Since P = V²/R, power is proportional to V². If voltage halves, power reduces to one quarter of its original value.
Since P = V²/R, power is proportional to V². If voltage halves, power reduces to one quarter of its original value.
Since P = V²/R, power is proportional to V². If voltage halves, power reduces to one quarter of its original value.

toLevel4.sentence: Energy efficiency compares useful energy {{blank:1}} to total energy input, expressed as a percentage.

1.correctExplanation: Efficiency = (useful energy output / total energy input) × 100%. No device is 100% efficient; some energy is always converted to waste heat.

distractors.explanation: Efficiency = (useful energy output / total energy input) × 100%. No device is 100% efficient; some energy is always converted to waste heat.
Efficiency = (useful energy output / total energy input) × 100%. No device is 100% efficient; some energy is always converted to waste heat.
Efficiency = (useful energy output / total energy input) × 100%. No device is 100% efficient; some energy is always converted to waste heat.

toLevel4.sentence: A {{blank:1}} is a unit of energy equal to 3600 joules.

1.correctExplanation: 1 Wh = 1 W × 3600 s = 3600 J. This is 1/1000 of a kilowatt-hour. Battery capacities in small devices are often given in Wh.

distractors.explanation: 1 Wh = 1 W × 3600 s = 3600 J. This is 1/1000 of a kilowatt-hour. Battery capacities in small devices are often given in Wh.
1 Wh = 1 W × 3600 s = 3600 J. This is 1/1000 of a kilowatt-hour. Battery capacities in small devices are often given in Wh.
1 Wh = 1 W × 3600 s = 3600 J. This is 1/1000 of a kilowatt-hour. Battery capacities in small devices are often given in Wh.

toLevel5.question: Analyse why the power rating on a light bulb assumes a specific voltage, and what happens when the actual voltage differs.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: A '60 W, 240 V' bulb only dissipates 60 W at 240 V. At 220 V, P = (220/240)² × 60 ≈ 50 W — dimmer but longer-lasting. At higher voltage, more power but shorter life.
distractors: Power rating is always accurate regardless of voltage
Bulbs automatically adjust to maintain rated power
Voltage has no effect on actual power
toLevel5.correct: Power ratings assume rated voltage; at different voltages, actual power changes as P = V²/R, affecting brightness and lifespan

toLevel5.question: Compare the energy efficiency of transmitting electrical power at 240 V versus 240,000 V over the same distance. Explain using P = I²R.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: For the same power P = IV, increasing V by 1000× reduces I by 1000×. Since loss = I²R, losses reduce by 10⁶ (one million times). This is why high voltage transmission is used.
distractors: Both voltages result in the same losses
toLevel5.correct: Higher voltage means lower current for the same power, so I²R losses are dramatically reduced

toLevel5.question: Evaluate the environmental implications of standby power in household devices. If 20 devices each draw 5 W on standby 24/7, what is the annual energy waste?
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Total standby power = 20 × 5 = 100 W. Annual energy = 0.1 kW × 8760 h = 876 kWh. At $0.30/kWh, this costs $263 per year in wasted electricity.
toLevel5.correct: 876 kWh per year — equivalent to running a heater for over 400 hours

toLevel5.question: A regenerative braking system in an electric car converts kinetic energy back to electrical energy at 85% efficiency. If the car has 100 kJ of kinetic energy, analyse the power output if braking occurs over 5 seconds.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Recovered energy = 0.85 × 100,000 = 85,000 J. Power = E/t = 85,000/5 = 17,000 W = 17 kW. The remaining 15 kJ is lost as heat.

toLevel5.question: Analyse why instantaneous power (p = dE/dt) differs from average power (P = E/t) and when each is more useful.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: A microwave might average 800 W but briefly peak at 1500 W when the magnetron cycles. Peak power determines circuit breaker requirements; average determines energy cost.
distractors: Only average power exists in real circuits
toLevel5.correct: Instantaneous power shows power at a specific moment; average power shows overall rate — instantaneous matters for peak loads, average for billing

toLevel5.question: Compare the energy storage of a 5000 mAh phone battery at 3.7 V versus a 2000 mAh laptop battery at 11.1 V in terms of total energy.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Phone: E = 5 Ah × 3.7 V = 18.5 Wh = 66.6 kJ. Laptop: E = 2 Ah × 11.1 V = 22.2 Wh = 79.9 kJ. Higher voltage compensates for lower charge capacity.
distractors: Phone stores more energy because it has more mAh
Energy cannot be compared between different voltages
toLevel5.correct: Phone: 66.6 kJ (18.5 Wh); Laptop: 79.9 kJ (22.2 Wh) — laptop stores more energy despite fewer mAh

toLevel5.question: Evaluate the concept of 'power density' (watts per kilogram) and why it matters for electric vehicle battery design.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Power density determines how quickly a battery can release energy. High power density enables rapid acceleration. Energy density (Wh/kg) determines range. Both matter for EV performance.
distractors: Power density only affects the battery's weight
Higher power density means longer range
Power density and energy density are the same
toLevel5.correct: Higher power density means the battery can deliver energy faster relative to its weight, enabling better acceleration

toLevel5.question: Analyse why a 1 kW solar panel rarely produces 1 kW of power in practice.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Solar panel ratings use Standard Test Conditions (STC). Real output varies with cloud cover, panel angle, temperature (hot reduces output), dirt, and degradation over time. Actual output is typically 15-25% of rated peak.
distractors: Solar panels always produce their rated power
Only voltage varies, power stays constant
toLevel5.correct: The rating is for peak conditions (direct sunlight, 25°C, clean surface); real conditions include clouds, angle, temperature, and aging effects

toLevel5.sentence: Power density measures the rate of energy delivery per unit {{blank:1}} or volume of a battery.

1.correctExplanation: Power density (W/kg) indicates how quickly a battery can deliver energy relative to its weight. This is distinct from energy density (Wh/kg) which measures total energy capacity.

distractors.explanation: Power density (W/kg) indicates how quickly a battery can deliver energy relative to its weight. This is distinct from energy density (Wh/kg) which measures total energy capacity.
Power density (W/kg) indicates how quickly a battery can deliver energy relative to its weight. This is distinct from energy density (Wh/kg) which measures total energy capacity.
Power density (W/kg) indicates how quickly a battery can deliver energy relative to its weight. This is distinct from energy density (Wh/kg) which measures total energy capacity.

toLevel5.sentence: The efficiency of energy transfer is calculated as the ratio of {{blank:1}} energy output to total energy input.

1.correctExplanation: Efficiency only counts energy in the desired form. A light bulb's useful output is light; the heat produced is waste. Efficiency = useful output ÷ total input × 100%.

distractors.explanation: Efficiency only counts energy in the desired form. A light bulb's useful output is light; the heat produced is waste. Efficiency = useful output ÷ total input × 100%.
Efficiency only counts energy in the desired form. A light bulb's useful output is light; the heat produced is waste. Efficiency = useful output ÷ total input × 100%.
Efficiency only counts energy in the desired form. A light bulb's useful output is light; the heat produced is waste. Efficiency = useful output ÷ total input × 100%.
